title: Erdős Problem #1123: Boolean Algebras Modulo Density Zero Sets
description: Are B₁ = P(ℕ)/I₁ and B₂ = P(ℕ)/I₂ isomorphic, where I₁, I₂ are the density-zero and log-density-zero ideals? Set-theoretically dependent: YES under CH (Just-Krawczyk 1984).

overview.historicalContext: This problem arose from Erdős's visit to Ulam in Madison, Wisconsin in 1943-44. They believed they had proved non-isomorphism, but the proof was 'lost' and never reconstructed. Erdős wrote: 'The proof is gone and nobody can prove it.' He offered $100 for a resolution. Just and Krawczyk (1984) proved that under the Continuum Hypothesis, the algebras ARE isomorphic - a surprising positive answer to a question posed negatively.
overview.problemStatement: Let B₁ be the Boolean algebra P(ℕ)/I₁ where I₁ is the ideal of density-zero sets (d(A) = 0 means |A ∩ {1,...,n}|/n → 0). Let B₂ be P(ℕ)/I₂ where I₂ is the ideal of logarithmic-density-zero sets (δ(A) = 0 means (1/log n)·Σ_{k∈A, k≤n} 1/k → 0). Prove that B₁ and B₂ are not isomorphic as Boolean algebras.
overview.proofStrategy: The resolution is set-theoretically dependent. Just and Krawczyk (1984) showed that under the Continuum Hypothesis (CH), both algebras have cardinality ℵ₁ and satisfy similar saturation properties, enabling a back-and-forth construction of an isomorphism. Without CH, the question may have a different answer. The formalization captures the density definitions, the quotient Boolean algebra construction, and the conditional isomorphism result.
keyInsights: Natural density 0 implies logarithmic density 0, but not conversely
Both P(ℕ)/I₁ and P(ℕ)/I₂ are Boolean algebras
Under CH, both algebras have cardinality ℵ₁
Saturation properties under CH enable back-and-forth isomorphism
The isomorphism question is independent of ZFC
Erdős-Ulam's lost 'proof' of non-isomorphism was likely erroneous

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #1123 is SET-THEORETICALLY DEPENDENT. The question of whether B₁ = P(ℕ)/(density zero) and B₂ = P(ℕ)/(log-density zero) are isomorphic depends on set-theoretic axioms. Just and Krawczyk (1984) proved that under the Continuum Hypothesis, they ARE isomorphic. This resolved the $100 question, though not in the way Erdős and Ulam originally expected - they believed non-isomorphism held unconditionally.
conclusion.implications: This problem beautifully illustrates the interaction between number theory (density concepts), algebra (Boolean algebras), and set theory (independence results). It shows that even natural-seeming algebraic questions can be undecidable in ZFC. The result contributed to the broader study of quotient Boolean algebras P(ω)/I, which remains an active area of set-theoretic research.
openQuestions: What happens without CH - are there models where B₁ ≇ B₂?
Classification of P(ω)/I for other natural ideals
